# Tutorials Docs

## Tutorials

- [Choose your first lesson](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/csharp/tour-of-csharp/tutorials/index.md): Learn C# using GitHub Codespaces, and get started with your own development environment.
- [Hello world and text](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/csharp/tour-of-csharp/tutorials/hello-world.md): In this tutorial, you create your first C# apps. You write C# code and learn basic structure and types in C#.
- [Numbers in C#](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/csharp/tour-of-csharp/tutorials/numbers-in-csharp.md): This tutorial teaches you about the numeric types in C#. The tutorial contains a series of lessons that explore numbers and math operations in C#.
- [Tuples and types](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/csharp/tour-of-csharp/tutorials/tuples-and-types.md): This tutorial teaches you to create types in C#. You write C# code and see the results of compiling and running your code as you learn the structure of types.
- [Branches and loops](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/csharp/tour-of-csharp/tutorials/branches-and-loops.md): In this tutorial about branches and loops, you write C# code to explore the language syntax that supports conditional branches and loops to execute statements repeatedly. You write C# code and see the results of compiling and running your code directly in the browser.
- [List collections](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/csharp/tour-of-csharp/tutorials/list-collection.md): In this tutorial, you use GitHub Codespaces to learn about C# collections. You write C# code and see the results of compiling and running your code in the Codespaces environment.
- [Pattern matching](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/docs/refs/heads/llmstxt/docs/csharp/tour-of-csharp/tutorials/pattern-matching.md): In this tutorial about pattern matching, you learn C#. You're going to write C# code and see the results of compiling and running your code.
